com.isoterik.mgdx.ai.fsm

Class ManagedStateMachine<E,S extends com.badlogic.gdx.ai.fsm.State<E>>

  • java.lang.Object
    • com.badlogic.gdx.ai.fsm.DefaultStateMachine<E,com.badlogic.gdx.ai.fsm.State<E>>
      • com.isoterik.mgdx.ai.fsm.ManagedStateMachine<E,S>
  • Type Parameters:
    E - the type of the entity handled by this state machine
    S - the type of state managed by this state machine
    All Implemented Interfaces:
    com.badlogic.gdx.ai.fsm.StateMachine<E,com.badlogic.gdx.ai.fsm.State<E>>, com.badlogic.gdx.ai.msg.Telegraph

    public class ManagedStateMachine<E,S extends com.badlogic.gdx.ai.fsm.State<E>>
extends com.badlogic.gdx.ai.fsm.DefaultStateMachine<E,com.badlogic.gdx.ai.fsm.State<E>>
    A ManagedStateMachine uses Transitions to automatically manage transitions between states. The state machine uses given Transitions to determine the current state and the next state.

    Because it is a finite state machine, in addition to the global state, this machine can only be in one state at any given time. Transitions are evaluated from first to last. If more than one Transition is triggered, the first evaluated transition will determine the current state, others are ignored!

    This state machine does not allow explicit change of states (except the global and initial state). If you need more control, use DefaultStateMachine instead.

    See Also:
    StateMachine, Transition

      • update

        public void update()
        This updates the state machine. The current state will be determined using available Transitions. Transitions are evaluated in the order in which they were added, first to last.
        Specified by:
